Blight.Cause: Fungal disease (often Exserohilum turcicum) affecting maize leaves, surviving on crop residue and spreading by wind or rain-splash.
Blight.Symptoms: Long, cigar-shaped grey-green to tan lesions on leaves, running parallel to leaf margins; lesions may coalesce to kill leaf tissues.
Precautions: Remove or bury infected plant debris after harvest.
Use resistant hybrids and avoid continuous maize cropping.
Ensure good air circulation and avoid prolonged leaf wetness.

Chemical: Apply foliar fungicide (e.g., propiconazole) at early symptoms.
Repeat spray at recommended intervals when weather conditions favour disease.
Organic: Use crop rotation with non-host crops.
Encourage residue decomposition and avoid heavy inoculum build-up.

Common Rust.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Puccinia sorghi; spores travel by wind and infect maize under cool, wet conditions.
Common Rust.Symptoms: Small, circular to elongated brown-reddish pustules (urediniospores) on both leaf surfaces; may develop yellow halo; in severe cases leaf chlorosis and death.
Precautions: Select resistant hybrids and plant early to avoid peak spore arrival.
Maintain good field hygiene, eliminate alternate hosts if present.
Monitor crop regularly during humid/cool periods.

Chemical: Apply fungicide when pustules first appear and conditions favour spread.
Use products with multiple modes of action to prevent resistance.
Organic: Maintain crop vigor with proper nutrition and irrigation to reduce susceptibility.
Remove heavily infected plants if feasible to reduce inoculum.

Gray Leaf Spot.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Cercospora zeaeâ€‘maydis or Cercospora zeina; survives on maize residue and flourishes under warm humid conditions and poor tillage.
Gray Leaf Spot.Symptoms: Tan to brown rectangular lesions on lower leaves, parallel to veins; as disease progresses lesions turn greyish, elongate, and may cover entire leaves.
Precautions: Use crop rotation and reduce conservation tillage to lower residue-borne inoculum.
Select hybrids with resistance, avoid continuous maize cropping.
Ensure proper spacing and ventilation; protect leaf area during grain-fill.

Chemical: Apply foliar fungicide before large lesion development when disease pressure is high.
Ensure timely fungicide applications aligned with disease progression.
Organic: Manage crop residue (bury or remove) to reduce inoculum load.
Improve plant health via balanced fertilisation and irrigation to reduce disease severity.

Healthy.Cause: No infection or physiological disorder detected; crop is growing under optimal conditions.
Healthy.Symptoms: Uniform green leaves, proper fruit/cob set, no visible lesions, spots or discoloration.
Precautions: Maintain balanced nutrition and irrigation schedule.
Inspect regularly for early signs of disease or pests.
Keep tools and equipment clean; practise proper field hygiene.

Chemical: No treatment required; maintain preventive fungicide/insecticide schedule if local risk is high.
Organic: Use organic amendments and compost to strengthen crop resilience.
Adopt integrated pest/disease management practices routinely.
